Package com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read

Provides classes for reading web shortcut files

See:
          Description

Class Summary
DesktopShortcutReader Reads Desktop shortcuts (FreeDesktop shortcuts with a .desktop extension - used by Linux, etc.).
ShortcutContents A container which holds a shortcut's name and URL.
ShortcutReader Parent class for readers.
ShortcutReadUtil Provides helper functions for reading shortcuts.
UrlShortcutReader Reads URL shortcuts (Windows shortcuts with a .url extension).
WeblocShortcutReader Reads Webloc shortcuts (Apple/Mac/OSX shortcuts with a .webloc extension).
WebsiteShortcutReader Reads Website shortcuts (Windows shortcuts with a .website extension).
 

Exception Summary
ShortcutReadException Used to indicate when there is an exception reading a shortcut file or stream.
 

Package com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read Description

Provides classes for reading web shortcut files

Ideally, you should have direct access to the shortcut file. In this case, the preferred way to read files is to use the read or readUrlString methods in the ShortcutReadUtil class. Note that these methods determine the type of shortcut by looking at the file extension in the file name, so they will not work properly if the extension is incorrect. A usage example follows: 

 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.ShortcutReadUtil;
 
 File myFile = new File("shortcut.desktop");
 
 String url = ShortcutReadUtil.readUrlString(myFile);
 
 ShortcutContents contents = ShortcutReadUtil.read(myFile);
 String name = contents.getName();
 String url = contents.getUrlString();

Note that you can retrieve the name/title of the shortcut. The name returned by the readers is a guess. Many shortcut files do not contain a name/title embedded in the file. ".desktop" shortcuts may contain several embedded names with different encodings. Unfortunately, these names are not necessarily updated when the shortcut is renamed. It is difficult, if not impossible, to determine which is the correct name. As of right now, the reader will always return the name of the file as the name of the shortcut, although this may change in the future.

Methods are also provided for retrieving the appropriate reader class for a given file or to check if a file has a valid extension (see ShortcutReadUtil.getShortcutReader and ShortcutReadUtil.hasValidExtension).

If you are reading the shortcut from a stream and know the type of shortcut, then you should instantiate the appropriate reader class ( DesktopShortcutReader UrlShortcutReader, WebsiteShortcutReader, or WeblocShortcutReader) and then call the readUrlString method. A usage example follows: 

 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.ShortcutReader;
 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.DesktopShortcutReader;
 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.UrlShortcutReader;
 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.WebsiteShortcutReader;
 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.WeblocShortcutReader;
 
 ShortcutReader reader = new DesktopShortcutReader();
   OR
 ShortcutReader reader = new UrlShortcutReader();
   OR
 ShortcutReader reader = new WebsiteShortcutReader();
   OR
 ShortcutReader reader = new WeblocShortcutReader();
 
 String url = reader.readUrlString(inputStream);

If you are reading the shortcut from a stream but do not know the type of shortcut, then you must use the ShortcutReadUtil.readUrlStringTrialAndError method. As the name implies, this method tries reading the stream as each type of shortcut to see which one works. Due to buffering limitations, there is a small chance that this method will not work. A usage example follows: 

 import com.abcodeworks.webshortcututil.read.ShortcutReadUtil;
 
 String url = ShortcutReadUtil.readUrlStringTrialAndError(inputStream);

The methods that read from streams do not close the streams (this is the responsibility of the caller).
